conclusion: Sphere A is stationary on the inclined plane, and the tension in the wire is zero, meaning all forces acting on sphere A are balanced.
Sphere A is on an inclined plane at angle Î¸, connected by a wire parallel to the plane, and sphere B is to the right of sphere A at a horizontal distance d.
The forces acting on sphere A include gravitational force, electrostatic force, and normal force.
The gravitational force on sphere A is \( mg \), decomposed into components \( mg \sin\theta \) (parallel to the inclined plane) and \( mg \cos\theta \) (perpendicular to the inclined plane).
The electrostatic force between spheres A and B is \( F_{\text{elec}} = k \frac{q^2}{d^2} \), acting horizontally to the right.
The normal force \( N_A \) exerted by the inclined plane balances the perpendicular component of the gravitational force \( mg \cos\theta \).
For sphere A to remain stationary, the net force along the inclined plane must be zero.
The component of the electrostatic force along the inclined plane is \( F_{\text{elec, parallel}} = F_{\text{elec}} \cos\theta = k \frac{q^2}{d^2} \cos\theta \).
The gravitational force along the inclined plane is \( F_{\text{gravity, parallel}} = mg \sin\theta \).
For equilibrium along the inclined plane, \( F_{\text{elec, parallel}} = F_{\text{gravity, parallel}} \).
Substituting the expressions for the forces gives \( k \frac{q^2}{d^2} \cos\theta = mg \sin\theta \).
Taking the square root of both sides gives \( \frac{q}{d} = \sqrt{\frac{mg \sin\theta}{k \cos\theta}} \).
